webTitle: Disney hounded for its portrayal of Dalmatians

fields.headline: Disney hounded for its portrayal of Dalmatians
fields.trailText: Animal activists claim that the Disney empire is promoting unhealthy stereotypes of the zippy, black-and-white canines, resulting in abuse and abandonment for many dogs.
fields.body:
Animal activists claim that the Disney empire, which is behind 1996's successful 101 Dalmatians and is currently filming 102 Dalmatians, is promoting unhealthy stereotypes of the zippy, black-and-white canines.

Although Dalmatians are in fact highly strung and can be unpredictable with children, strangers and other dogs, Disney's films portray them as warm and cuddly. As a result, commercial kennels churn them out in time for Christmas, and owners abuse and abandon them when they don't live up to their image, say activists.

"Disney is making a fortune off these dogs but they don't bear any responsibility for the overbreeding and... abuse they suffer later on when they're no longer cute little puppies," said activist Ann Herrington.

The number of abandoned Dalmatians has increased more than 100% since before the 1996 Disney film was released, said Teri Austin of the Los Angeles-based Amanda Foundation. The Foundation anticipates "another glut of poorly bred and abused dogs" following the release of the sequel.

The Disney empire licensed more than 17,000 items of merchandise that tied in to 101 Dalmatians, including porcelain eggs, boxer shorts, bedlinen, soap and diamond-studded pens, the activists said. They added that Disney is sure to have more such products out in time for the sequel.

A Disney spokesman had no immediate comment on the charge, but last Friday the company announced that it will work with the Dalmatian Club of America to promote pet adoption and selection awareness in conjunction with the release of 102 Dalmatians in November.

Richard Cook, chairman of the Walt Disney Motion Pictures Group, also said that one of the main themes of 102 Dalmatians involves animal shelters, and the movie promotes responsible pet ownership.

fields.headline: A faithful composer
fields.standfirst:
Pénélope
****
Edinburgh Festival Theatre

Special report: the Edinburgh festival 2000
fields.trailText:
Pénélope
****
Edinburgh Festival Theatre
fields.body:
Gabriel Fauré's Pénélope, composed in 1907, is one of those unfortunate operas that has been obscured between Wagner on one hand and Debussy on the other. But as this concert performance showed, Pénélope contains music and drama of consummate mastery. Even if Fauré's music acknowledges its debt to Wagner with a web of leitmotifs, Pénélope's idiom is recognisably Fauré's own.

What makes the opera so original is the symbiotic relationship between Fauré's magical scoring and his unique harmonic sense. Although the piece is indebted to lush, late-19th-century chromatic harmony, there's something classical about the ambience of Fauré's soundworld. Everything is reined-in and contained, yet there are some startling, prophetic moments. When Pénélope uncovers her loom, Fauré's accompaniment is a simple bed of string and harp sonority. But the voicing of this chord transforms it into something compelling and strange.

Even if the pace of the music is languid, Fauré's concision creates a persuasive dramatic momentum. The story is an unfussy telling of the return of Ulysseto his home, Ithaca, and his plan to kill the suitors who have been tormenting his wife. Pénélope carries everyone else in her lamenting wake. Other characters are reduced to their dramatic function as part of the plot to save her. The suitors, headed by Christopher Maltman's Eurymaque, are priapic villains with no redeeming qualities; Donald Maxwell's Eumée is a rustic do-gooder; and there is a bevy of silly serving-girls.

Soprano Michelle DeYoung's Pénélope has a towering presence. The fullness of her voice is matched by the fluidity of her phrasing. And on the few occasions when Fauré calls for it, she has huge, declamatory power at the very summit of her voice. Tenor Michael Schade is vengefully heroic as Ulysse, and provides enthusiastic energy to contrast with Pénélope's mostly reflective music. The BBC Scottish Symphony Orchestra are conducted by Jean-Yves Ossonce with convincing sympathy for one of Fauré's most important and most neglected works.

webTitle: Review:  The 12 Cellists of the Berlin Philharmonic

fields.headline: The darting dozen
fields.standfirst:
The 12 Cellists of the Berlin Philharmonic
*****
Royal Albert Hall, London
fields.trailText:
The 12 Cellists of the Berlin Philharmonic
*****
Royal Albert Hall, London
fields.body:
One of the most extraordinary - some would say bizarre - of chamber ensembles, the Twelve Cellists of the Berlin Philharmonic came into being almost by accident in 1972, when the composer Julius Klengel wrote a piece called Hymnus for the orchestra's cello section.

Intended for radio broadcast, Hymnus was initially planned as a one-off, but the idea of an all-cello band stuck, and from then on the ensemble has gone from strength to strength, commissioning new works and playing transcriptions of everything from Bach to the Beatles. Their Proms debut was an unqualified triumph. A whiff of cabaret pervaded. Raffish in white tuxedos, they had an air of the big bands of yesteryear, while their leader, Georg Faust, introduced their programme from the platform.

The centrepiece was 12 Angry Men by the Australian composer and former Berlin Philharmonic viola player Brett Dean. The work takes its title and theme from Sidney Lumet's classic 1957 courtroom movie, in which one juror gradually managed to convince the 11 others that the defendant in the dock may be innocent of the murder of which he is accused. Dean's ingenious composition flawlessly binds drama with form, employing a composite structure in which an eruptive, dissonant toccata (depicting the 11 angry jurors) first collides with, then gives way to, a lyrical theme and variations instigated by the leader. Its course doesn't always run smooth - there are a number of technically exacting explosions before something like order is restored. The ending, in which a certain growling resentment simmers beneath the calm, has an ambivalence worthy of Strauss's Zarathustra - which has always been one of the Berlin Philarmonic's show stoppers.

French composer Jean Françaix wrote his Aubade for the cellists in 1974. It has a deco nostalgia, redolent of the chic world of interwar Paris where Françaix initially made his mark. The finale, an exhilarating scramble, was apparently inspired by racing at Le Mans, where Francaix was born. No cello ensemble concert would be complete, however without the music of Heitor Villa-Lobos, two of whose glorious Bachianas Brasilieras - Nos 1 and 5 - were written for such a group.

No 1 turns toe-tapping folk music into thrilling toccatas and fugues. No 5 is the one with the famous soprano solo, its cantilena exquisitely voiced by Juanita Lascarro, though she was slightly less assured in the central and closing sections where a more punchy delivery is required. The playing throughout was extraordinary and the audience screamed its approval after every number, refusing to let them go until they and Lascarro had given an encore - one of Astor Piazzolla's most haunting tangos.

webTitle: Retailers warn that e-day will cause cash crisis

fields.headline: Retailers warn that e-day will cause cash crisis
fields.standfirst: Special report: Economic and Monetary Union
fields.trailText: Europe's biggest retailers are worried that a shortage of coins and notes could leave checkouts in chaos when the euro currency goes into everyday circulation in 2002.
fields.body:
Europe's biggest retailers are worried that a shortage of coins and notes could leave checkouts in chaos when the euro currency goes into everyday circulation in 2002.

The European Retail Round Table, which represents Tesco, Sainsbury and continental firms such as Carrefour and Metro, has raised the concern in a letter to European Union finance ministers.

In a separate development, individual retailers have warned that introduction of the currency could trigger a flood of forgeries into the continental economy, as fraudsters take advantage of consumers' unfamiliarity with the new cash.

Matt Collins, president of Tesco's French operations, said he had been pressing for months for samples of the new notes and coins to be made available so that his staff could get used to them.

Mr Collins said: "People need to see it and feel it in advance. It's a security concern. Forgeries will hit the market on day one and we'll have absolutely no idea what the money is supposed to feel like."

The European Central Bank has drawn up detailed guidelines for introduction of the euro in participating countries on the first trading day of 2002. It decided that money could be distributed to retailers a few days in advance but that they could not put it into circulation until launch day.

Countries can circulate coins to members of the public a few days in advance, but notes will be held back until January 1.

In its letter to finance ministers, the European Retail Round Table has asked for a rethink to allow for some distribution of notes in advance, arguing that otherwise shops will have to hold thousands of pounds worth of extra change.

It cites research by the continental business schools Insead and WHU Koblenz, which warns of a worst-case scenario in which shops will have to close their doors within hours, after running out of the new money. The letter claims the cash economy could "crash" within hours of the currency's launch unless the problem is tackled.

Mr Collins backed the call for a rethink: "For a big change like this, anything they can do in advance will help ease the problem."

A spokesman for Marks & Spencer, which has more than 20 stores in euroland, declined to comment on specific measures for distributing the new cash but said: "We've been in discussions on this for the last nine months. We, along with other retailers, are making sure in talks with government and industry bodies that we find the easiest, least problematic solution."

webTitle: Airtours casts off from luxury cruising

fields.headline: Airtours casts off from luxury cruising
fields.standfirst: Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: Holiday group Airtours yesterday announced plans to pull out of the luxury cruise sector by disposing of its 50% stake in Italy's Costa Crociere to one of its own shareholders, Carnival Corp.
fields.body:
Holiday group Airtours yesterday announced plans to pull out of the luxury cruise sector by disposing of its 50% stake in Italy's Costa Crociere to one of its own shareholders, Carnival Corp.

Airtours, under financial pressure after problems with its German and North American operations, booked itself a handsome profit by selling for £350m the 50% stake it bought for £2.25m in Costa Crociere only three years ago.

Carnival, which already controls the other half of the Italian company and owns 26% of Airtours, will consolidate its position as the world's largest cruise ship operator with 48 vessels.

It plans to use its stronger position in Europe to invest in new tonnage and the moves could squeeze other competitors such as P&O, which plans a separate listing for its cruise operation this autumn. The windfall cash from the sale will be used to reduce indebtedness at Airtours which earlier this month reported a massive downturn in quarterly profits to June 30.

It said its annual results would be scarred by the under-performance of its German operation, Frosch Touristik, in which it has a 36% holding, and the general downturn in the US market.

Airtours chairman David Crossland said it still had its eye on expansion in the future.

"The proceeds will put us in an even better position to invest in business areas both in Europe and North America, which provide attractive opportunities for strong growth in profits and cashflow."

Airtours said it was selling its stake because the European cruise market was becoming increasingly competitive and players needed large amounts of investment in new ships to stay ahead.

But the company stressed that the decision on Costa Crociere would not affect its own mid-market Sun Cruises operation which provides fly-cruise packages to its in-house tour operators.

Costa Crociere has a fleet of seven ships offering cruises through the Mediterranean, northern Europe, South America and the Caribbean.

fields.headline: Taverner Consort/ Parrott
fields.standfirst:
****
McEwan Hall, Edinburgh

Special report: the Edinburgh festival 2000
fields.trailText:
****
McEwan Hall, Edinburgh
fields.body:
The enormous rotunda of Edinburgh's McEwan Hall is a fantastical, Victorian vision of the Italian Renaissance. As such, it was an appropriate place to stage a performance of Monteverdi's 1610 Vespers, part of the Edinburgh festival's Music of the Millennium series.

Andrew Parrott and the Taverner Consort, Choir and Players made full use of the spatial possibilities presented by so elaborate a setting. In the Gloria of the Magnificat, the two tenors Charles Daniels and Joseph Cornwell were placed on high balconies at either end of the building. Between them, singing from the stage, a third, counter-tenor voice sang the unadorned Gloria plainchant: a point of musical stillness amid a storm of celestial ornamentation in the two tenor parts. Daniels and Cornwell's call and response was ethereal, as their voices intermingled in the vast resonance of the hall.

Parrott positioned the chant choir. The austerity of these chants was at a physical as well as musical remove from the invention of the instrumental and vocal soloists on stage. Their roles in Monteverdi's psalms and concertos are dazzlingly diverse; from dramatic individual interjections to collective, choral reflection.

Parrott's vision was of the Vespers as compositional cornucopia. Each of Monteverdi's extemporisations on psalm themes was carefully delineated. Lauda Jerusalem had a voluptuous flow, an image of the Lord's generosity and power. This joyous polyphony contrasted with the seriousness of Monteverdi's part-writing in the Dixit Dominus, a depiction of God's vengeance. Parrott and his ensemble relished the musical and poetic puns of the Audi Coelum, a game between a tenor and an echoing second singer, who repeats the final syllables of the solo part.

But Monteverdi splits up his setting so that the repeated voice transforms the meaning of the solo: the first tenor's "vita" (life), for example, is echoed as "ita" (even so). Parrott concealed the shadowing tenor behind the organ, his voice seemingly an actual echo of Joseph Cornwell's singing.

The instrumental contributions were no less convincing. In the Sonata sopra Sancta Maria, the ensemble became an ecstatic congregation, responding to counter tenor James Huw Jeffries. The juxtaposition between this worldly abundance and the final prayers, declaimed without any elaboration by the choir, embodied the spiritual and musical variety of the whole performance.

fields.headline: RSA considers part flotation of investment arm
fields.standfirst: Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: Insurance group Royal & Sun Alliance is considering a part flotation of its rapidly growing fund management business, which has £60bn of investments and could be valued at up to £1bn.
fields.body:
Insurance group Royal & Sun Alliance is considering a part flotation of its rapidly growing fund management business, which has £60bn of investments and could be valued at up to £1bn.

Industry sources yesterday confirmed that the step was under consideration because Royal & Sun Alliance feels its asset management activities are overlooked in its present stock market valuation.

The insurance group has been trying to develop Royal & Sun Alliance Investments as a separate business, providing investment services for third parties as well as managing the proceeds of the group's own retail insurance sales.

About £6bn of its existing assets have come from outside the group and directors want to increase the proportion.

RSA Investments has just been moved into separate premises in central London as part of the effort to establish its own identity. Flotation of a mi nority stake would have the added benefit of allowing the company to reward senior staff with share option packages.

Royal & Sun Alliance has been having a good run recently, recovering from a difficult merger two years ago. This month the company reported a 5% rise in first-half operating profits and said it was on course to meet its target rates for operating efficiencies.

The company's shares have risen by 60% since March, closing on Friday at 480p. However, asset management businesses typically command a higher stock market rating than insurers; groups such as Amvescap and Aberdeen Asset Management have seen their share prices more than triple over the past year.

Royal & Sun Alliance's chief executive, Bob Mendelsohn, has attracted criticism during his two-year tenure. Reporting the group's interim results, he said he believed the company had turned a corner in the public's perception.

fields.headline: It gets under your skin
fields.standfirst:
Körper
****
The Playhouse, Edinburgh

Special report: the Edinburgh festival 2000
fields.trailText:
Körper
****
The Playhouse, Edinburgh
fields.body:
Hands in a hole in a wall grapple as the audience settle themselves. The great Berlin company Schaubühne am Lehniner Platz are throwing stuff at us even before the performance begins.

This company, which for the past 29 years has nurtured some of the great names of German dramatic theatre, has controversially had a change of identity. Last year Sasha Waltz became artistic director - she's young, female, and, what's more, a choreographer.

Supremely confident of this transformation, Waltz has chosen to make Körper (Bodies) the focus of her debut production with the company. As the lights dim, a group of dancers in dark suits begin a merciless slamming session. It makes you wince: those bones are making a lot of noise.

Meanwhile, stage left. A great black 10 metre-high monolith looming over the action suddenly reveals a saintly body flat-framed in a window of light. Another curls into view, and another, until 11 are oozing around together in this celestial elevator, white bodies stark against black. It's nude heaven featuring Lucian Freud's fleshy, soft-folded meat, Breugel's hellish medieval souls, the smooth marble piètas of the renaissance, the bodies of science - all rolling together in slow motion. A whole civilisation's worth of body beautiful crop ping up in one image. Only a wizard like Waltz could collect and dissect ideas with such skill, and only then with a company as individual and experienced as the one she has brought together.

For an hour and a half, the company whacks out an encyclopedic list of corporeal facts and fairy tales. The work flashes out myriad images of the body in art, in psychology, in medicine, in sport, in love, in society, in violence, in religion. At times there are bursts of pure, liquid dance, at others performers are grabbing handfuls of skin and carrying each other around. If you are ever lucky enough to see these Körper, you might want to pinch yourself at the end and check that you're still there.

webTitle: Officials promise to spell out clearing and settlement rules for merged exchange

fields.headline: London stands its ground
fields.standfirst: Officials promise to spell out clearing and settlement rules for merged exchange
fields.trailText: The London Stock Exchange will seek to bolster its defences later this week against a possible £800m hostile takeover from Sweden with the blueprint for one of the most contentious aspects of its agreed merger with Frankfurt's Deutsche Börse.
fields.byline: Mark Milner  and  Jane Martinson  in New York
fields.body:
The London Stock Exchange will seek to bolster its defences later this week against a possible £800m hostile takeover from Sweden with the blueprint for one of the most contentious aspects of its agreed merger with Frankfurt's Deutsche Börse.

Senior officials from both London and Frankfurt will be on hand as Clearstream and Crest detail plans on Thursday for how clearing and settlement will work under the iX merger proposal.

The issue has proved a critical one for the London and Frankfurt merger with members of both exchanges concerned about how clearing and settlement would work under the iX exchange and how much it would cost.

Yesterday David Cowan, the head of public affairs at Clearstream - which is 50% owned by the Frankfurt exchange - said the plans would mean "UK brokers would be able to go through Crest to settle German securities transactions and German brokers would be able to go to Clearstream to settle UK securities transactions". The plan would offer savings which would be "very high in percentage terms" though he declined to give an exact figure.

The likelihood of a two-way battle for the London exchange between OM Gruppen, the Swedish group which owns and operates the Stockholm exchange, and Deutsche Börse increased yesterday after the Frankfurt exchange hinted strongly it would counter any hostile move from Sweden by launching its own "white knight" counterbid.

OM, which had an approach turned down by the London exchange board at the end of last week, has promised to decide whether it will go ahead with a hostile bid "as soon as possible" with some reports suggesting an offer could come as early as today.

Deutsche Börse said it remained committed to the plan to merge with London and said that in the event of a hostile bid from OM "a change in the transaction structure to an offer is possible".

The London Stock Exchange appears to be reconciled to postponing the vote on the Frankfurt merger, due on September 14, if OM launches a hostile bid. "Were an offer to be made we would consider what the implications would be for the timetable and we would be mindful of the need to give shareholders full information and sufficient time to consider it," a spokesman said.

Meanwhile, both the Paris bourse and Nasdaq in the US are keeping the developing situation in London under close review. Euronext, the alliance of Paris, Amsterdam and Brussels exchanges, sought to recruit the London exchange in the spring without success and yesterday a spokeswoman for the Paris exchange said: "We are considering the situation."

Senior Nasdaq executives are understood to have been briefed about developments after the first reports of the approach by OM Gruppen at the end of last week.

Nasdaq, which runs the world's largest index devoted to hi-tech stocks, expects to complete its own joint venture with iX as soon as London and Frankfurt have formalised their partnership. Nasdaq refused to comment yesterday.

However, sources close to the US exchange said: "We plan to be in Europe and to have a global, 24-hour service. We have an agreement with iX because we think it makes the most sense for us. But if the situation changes then obviously we will adapt."

fields.headline: Dyke throws the dice
fields.standfirst:
Succeed and the BBC is saved. Fail and it will be in ruins. Matt Wells and Maggie Brown on a do-or-die gamble
Special report: the future of the BBC
fields.trailText: Succeed and the BBC is saved. Fail and it will be in ruins. Matt Wells and Maggie Brown on a do-or-die gamble
fields.body:
Just when it seemed that the last drop of ink had been squeezed out of the news at ten pen, the new director-general of the BBC had to go and refill the cartridge. There were the predictable howls of anger from the usual suspects; as Greg Dyke said in his keynote speech at the Guardian Edinburgh international television festival, propose any change at the BBC and you get accused of dumbing down. But the decision to force the likes of Michael Buerk and Peter Sissons to stay up later every night is not simply a scheduling move: it is the first salvo in a revolutionary transformation of the BBC channels.

In a pledge that may come back to haunt him, Dyke confidently predicted that a news bulletin at 10pm would get better ratings than at 9pm. It was, he said, the main reason for shifting the bulletin into the slot abandoned by ITV. As everyone listening to the speech knew, that was a classic BBC smokescreen: the main reason for moving the news to 10pm is to get better ratings for BBC1's peak-time shows. After just a year at the corporation, Dyke is already retreating behind the BBC double-speak that so many had hoped he would banish. Observers simply could not understand why he did not declare unashamedly that BBC1 should maintain its position as a mass-appeal channel chasing high ratings - the key justification of the licence fee.

Nevertheless, if he pulls it off, Dyke will earn himself the reputation of the man who saved the BBC from the ravages of the digital age, maintaining the corporation as a universal broadcaster at the centre of cultural life in Britain. The risks of the strategy cannot be underestimated: mess it up and the BBC will be left in ruins.

The MacTaggart lecture revealed Dyke to be far more than just a budget-cutting croissant-killer. He has a long-term, detailed and coherent vision for the BBC that is designed to take it into the digital age and preserve the public service broadcasting heritage to which it owes its present strength.

The portfolio of seven channels outlined by Dyke on Friday serves a broad constituency of British viewers, from those who wish simply to be entertained, others who want to widen their view of the world, to those who crave intellectual stimulation from the most cerebral of sources.

The channel propositions are clear: big-hitting entertainment, drama and factual programmes on BBC1, slightly more serious and innovative stuff on BBC2, music and comedy aimed at a youth audience on BBC3, and an "unashamedly intellectual" combination of Radio 3 and Radio 4 on the fourth network. Combined with two children's services, one for pre-school children and another for their older counterparts, plus BBC News 24, the result is a "suite" of channels for almost every constituency.

Less obvious is the corporation's capacity to deliver the Dyke vision. Scepticism dripped from bar stools all over Edinburgh at the weekend as Dyke's colleagues in the industry mulled over the most important challenges facing the country's national broadcaster since the onset of satellite television more than a decade ago. Dyke, speaking after his delivering his lecture, admitted that his proposition depended upon harnessing talent in a way never before achieved at the BBC. To make BBC1's prime-time schedule work, the corporation will need to fight harder than ever to win the watershed battle.

Citing Walking With Dinosaurs as the benchmark of quality for all genres, the director of television, Mark Thompson, says it will mean plenty of good entertainment, documentaries and natural history shows scheduled at the key 9pm "junction" - but in reality, it will be the quality of the BBC's drama that makes or breaks this particular fight. "We are under no illusions. This is the biggest creative challenge the BBC has ever faced," Thompson says.

Dyke is taking an unenviable gamble, pitching the corporation into a direct conflict with its main commercial competitor on the adult drama battleground that is awash with BBC blood. There is serious money - almost £500m over three years - to patch up the wounds, but some believe that it will take more than money to win the war.

Steve Hewlett, the director of programmes at Carlton, and a former BBC man, applauds the big picture. "It seems sound, a coherent vision of the BBC's television services for the future. That, I think, is positive. As a programme-making strategy, it is something that you could sign up to." But he sounds a warning over the practicalities. "The devil is in the detail. The BBC's apparent incapacity to come up with long-run, popular, returnable drama series to match ITV has got nothing to do with money. That is not the answer to this problem. There is a creative cultural problem within the BBC that goes deeper than lack of money."

Another senior ITV executive goes even further. There is a climate, he says, of "commissioning by fear". Peter Salmon, BBC1's controller, is so afraid of the consequences of any decision he makes that projects are delayed and risks avoided.

Peter Bazalgette, of Bazal Productions, makers of Big Brother, agrees: he did not offer the surprise hit to the BBC because it would have been more trouble than it was worth.

Hewlett believes that the cultural malaise at the BBC stems from the decision by Dyke's predecessor, John Birt, to split the broadcasting and production divisions. That meant that heads of creative departments became managers, desperate to sell as many of their products to the channel controllers as they could, with far less regard for quality.

Dyke has repaired the split, but, according to Hewlett, has installed a management and commissioning structure that is a political fudge. "From the outside, the structure is unclear, in terms of who's supposed to do what."

Even if the new structure works, there is a serious question over whether there is enough creative talent in the British television industry to sustain the populist proposition for BBC1, as well as the new demands for the other new services.

Dyke acknowledges the problem. "The nagging concern at the back of my mind is: is there the talent in this industry to provide the things we need?"

Nick Elliott, controller of drama at the ITV network, says there will be a battle for talented writers in particular. "It will be tough for the BBC: 8pm, not 9pm, will be its key point. There will be an extra episode of EastEnders, maybe on Sundays. They will build on that with pre- watershed family shows and they will try to get the writers we at ITV like."

Clearly, directing the new money in the right direction is going to be a key challenge. But almost as difficult will be convincing the public. It is thought that, at the current rate, it will not be too long before about half the country is signed up to digital television through subscription services. And as they migrate to the scores of new channels they find coming through their satellite dishes or set-top boxes, will they really still be prepared to shell out well over £100 a year to fund a set of channels they rarely watch? Then there is the other half who are reluctant to sign up to digital TV - why should they pay for a clutch of digital channels to which they have no access?

The broadcaster Jon Snow says the outlook for the licence fee is gloomy. "The British public's tolerance of the regressive tax that is the licence fee is living on borrowed time," he warns.

Dyke believes the way to protect the licence fee is through "universality" - a key theme to his Friday night lecture. The BBC's services must appeal in part to all viewers, and must be available free to everyone. That, he argues, is the justification for the licence fee and precisely the reason why the BBC's television channels have to change.

Alan Boyd, the chief executive of Pearson UK Production, and a former colleague of Dyke's, says the director-general will have a difficult balancing act, managing the development of the new networks while keeping onside those who do not yet possess the means to receive them. "The key thing he was talking about is universality and he has got to get this balance right."

Boyd is not as pessimistic as some. "There is talent in the industry. It's all about giving it focus and boxing it in. There has to be the 'young turk' feel - the confidence to fight for a programme you believe in."

fields.body:
* It wasn't long before there was blood on the carpet at the Guardian Edinburgh international television festival. Rival marketing gurus slugged it out in a battle to claim selling supremacy. Channel 4's lively director of strategy, David Brook, reeled at the accusation that "Big Brother is the worst kind of dumbed-down television". Who made this high-ground claim? Why Jim Hytner, marketing director of Channel 5. Natch.

* Congrats to David "Liberian four" Lloyd, Channel 4's head of news and current affairs, for his diplomatic coup in freeing the imperilled journalists accused of spying in the troubled African state. Fresh from the top-level negotiations, Lloyd was clearly in need of some pampering when he arrived in Edinburgh. "This room does have a castle view, doesn't it?" he demanded of the receptionist at the £200-a-night Balmoral Hotel.

* This year's festival was strangely haunted by the ghost of John Birt. Much talk centred on his notorious portrait - commissioned to join the other great and good DGs in the council chamber at Broadcasting House. Trouble is, it's too large for the standard slot and could only replace either Lord Reith or Hugh Carleton-Greene in the two prime places. So, BBC gossips insist, the portrait of Lord Birt forms a central plank of Greg Dyke's commitment to regionalism; like an icon of a particularly revered saint in the Russia of the tsars, it has been sent on a tour of the corporation's provincial outposts.

* Staff at the Edinburgh international conference centre, venue for the festival, have seen many things, but nothing prepared them for the session titles devised by Channel 5's director of programmes and the festival chairwoman, Dawn "Scary" Airey. They started out bravely announcing the titles to the upcoming session, but by the time they reached "Cocks on the Box" they came over all coy. Marketing "A Load of old Bollocks" proved the final straw - announcements ceased altogether after attempts to read out the session title in asterisks failed.

* Congratulations to the BBC on its latest - and not at all desperate - signing. School uniform-wearing pop star Britney Spears is to become an agony aunt for BBC Online, an onerous task which will (as the corporation's news site breathlessly tells us) coincide with her appearance "at number five in the UK singles chart with Lucky". She will be dispensing her excellent and judicious advice for two weeks from September 8; just before her week-long stint anchoring Newsnight while Jeremy Paxman is on holiday.

* From the ambitions of the Norsemen, Good Lord deliver us! Swedish firm Bonnier, currently launching a niche Scottish business paper in Edinburgh, seems to have put the fear of God into the established pink'un. Under the cover of summer holidays, the Financial Times is reported to be busily drawing up plans for a "baby" tabloid FT for British eyes only, selling for less than the hefty 85p price of the parent paper. Insiders say a team under UK news editor George Parker is hard at work, with the aim of heading off any challenge, should it arise, this autumn. One rival title - Sunday Business - is said to be quite enough for the FT to stomach.

* However, regular FT readers may have already noticed a certain raciness in news presentation creeping in: staid it is not. Last week's story about Altavista's "free surfing" climbdown was accompanied by a huge picture of the Daily Mail's front page when the offer was first made. Staff reporters have been told to cover the Big Brother phenomenon, summer specials have included pieces on how jumped-up Essex barrow boys burn their bonuses on new Porsches, while the paper's Saturday magazine carries contact ads. Is it all explained by by an FT bonus system for top editorial staff, based on a rise in sales? Old hands complain they are chasing circulation- boosting stories. The more paranoid even mutter about a risk of the paper becoming interesting.

* The diary's favourite media mogul's youngest son, James Murdoch, disappointed many on Sunday with his refusal to answer questions after delivering his alternative MacTaggart lecture at GEITF. Though NewsCorp spinners insist the company's lawyers banned him from interacting directly with his public due to sensitivities over the float of the company's broadcasting platforms, we remember all too well a similar refusal by his sister Elisabeth to answer questions after her Worldview lecture two years ago. Murdochs, it seems, do not have to be accountable.

* Gaiety is currently in short supply at Gay Times, where a blunder has resulted in 6,000 furious calls from readers. The monthly has just switched to a slightly bigger format, but failed to notify its subscription arm that the usual brown envelopes would now be too small. Result: the latest issue has been sent out in transparent wrappers, outing GT's entire subscription readership.

fields.headline: Tories accused of racism in row over foreign doctors' English
fields.trailText: August 8 2000: Dr Fox calls for English lessons for foreign doctors as "an issue of public safety"
fields.body:
John Prescott, the deputy prime minister, yesterday accused the Conservatives of stirring up "fear and prejudice" after the party claimed patient safety was being put at risk by overseas doctors with a poor grasp of English .

In a provocative intervention, the shadow health secretary, Liam Fox , pledged to introduce tough English tests to weed out foreign doctors whose language skills, he claimed, were jeopardising the safety of patients.

"Their English language skills are not up to scratch and patients are suffering as a result," Dr Fox said. "Correcting this is an issue of public safety."

His remarks were swiftly condemned by Mr Prescott. "The Tories stand for everything the Tories normally do -fear, prejudice and not delivering," he told the BBC's The World This Weekend.

The Liberal Democrats accused Dr Fox of "thinly veiled racism". Nick Harvey, the party's health spokesman, said: "This is disgraceful and a slap in the face for the many hard-working doctors who have come from abroad and give their all for the NHS.

"First their attack on asylum seekers and now this. The Tory party is getting nastier as it gets more desperate."

Last night one of the those involved in setting the English test for the British Council said: "This is absolute rubbish. The process doctors have to go through is very rigorous. It involves an academic understanding of English and an ability to set it in context." The standard required was the equivalent of the postgraduate level for university students.

Dr Fox, a rightwinger who practised as a GP before his election to parliament in 1992, sparked the row when he said a Tory government would introduce a tough English language test that might apply to overseas doctors already working in Britain.

Evan Harris, a Liberal Democrat health spokesman, and like Dr Fox a doctor turned politician, said foreign doctors already faced tough English tests.

"A lot of foreign doctors who work in Britain, particularly the Germans and Dutch, speak better English than us," he said. "Doctors from outside the European economic area have to pass the PLAB [professional and linguistic assessments board] test which has a very tough language component."

The Department of Health said it was up to NHS trusts to ensure doctors had adequate English . A new system of annual appraisals should show up any weaknesses.

fields.headline: White on black
fields.standfirst:
Racialist claims that black people are natural athletes give support to the idea they are naturally less intelligent

Special report: race issues in the UK
fields.trailText: Racialist claims that black people are natural athletes give support to the idea they are naturally less intelligent.
fields.body:
One wonders how Jack Nicklaus would explain Tiger Wood's success. In 1994 Nicklaus was asked why so few black people made it in golf. In response he pointed not to colour bars, the sport's socio-economic profile or the expense of taking it up professionally, but to biology. "They have different muscles that react in different ways," he said. Woods presumably inherited the specific sliver of DNA that deals with the swing, drive and putt from his mother's Malaysian side.

As a mammoth summer of sport comes to a crescendo with the Olympics, two certainties come with it. The first is that black athletes will shower themselves in glory and medals in the track events. The other is that in the minds and myths of many their success will further establish a relationship between race and sporting prowess.

Anecdotally the statistics are compelling. All the men's world running records from the 100 metres to the marathon are held by black people. No white man has ever run 100 metres in under 10 seconds - more than 200 black men have. All the finalists for the men's 100 metres in Sydney will be black.

Logic suggests this cannot be reduced to mere coincidence. But the search for an explanation would be laudable if some of the conclusions weren't so laughable. For prime among them is that black people are naturally better at sport. Their success, it is argued, is based not on conditions in the world into which they were born but what they were born into the world with.

Black people, they say, have "less subcutaneous fat on arms and legs", "smaller chest cavities", "a higher centre of gravity", "a longer arm span", "faster patellar tendon reflex", "greater body density", higher levels of plasma testosterone" and a "higher percentage of fast-twitch muscles". So there you go. Let us forget for a minute the glaring inconsistencies. The absence of black women from the equation; the history of race-mixing that makes race science a nonsense; that west African athletes, who are presumably of a similar racial make-up to their distant African-American cousins, do not excel at athletics; or that black athletic excellence does not extend to the likes of archery or rowing. Never mind all that. Black athletes do well because it is in their genes. On your marks. Get set. Go. I'll race you to the bell curve.

Those who hoped that Joe Louis felled such theories in 1938 when he knocked out the Nazi poster boy Max Schmeling are in for a shock. Racial determinism is back in vogue. Earlier this year the home secretary, Jack Straw, debated with Charles Murray, author of The Bell Curve, which claims that black people have, on average, an IQ 15 points lower than white people. Then came the book by Jon Entine, Taboo: Why Black Athletes Dominate Sports and Why We're Afraid to Talk About It. Next week the BBC will discuss it in The Faster Race.

The very title of Entine's book tells a story. Its passive-agressive tone locates it in the era of the backlash - part of a continuum that stretches from Newt Gingrich's Contract with America to the outbursts of the newly blond and now single Billy on Ally McBeal. This is the voice and the strategy of the Angry, White Male who must first claim victim-hood and then assert bravery in challenging a fictitious "liberal establishment" before peddling his prejudices.

For claiming that black athletes dominate sports is anything but "a taboo". It is a racist orthodoxy that fits hand-in-glove with that other long-established orthodoxy, that black people are stupid. Backing Entine's claim on television will be Professor Philippe Rushton, who believes that black people's brains are smaller than those of other races, leaving them less intelligent but more highly sexed and agressive. Rushton is reported to have paid 150 participants - 50 black, 50 white, 50 Asian - to answer questions on penis size. His conclusion? "It's a trade-off: more brain or more penis. You can't have everything."

A trade-off indeed. For if success is genetic, then why not failure too? "White men can't jump" is only a hop and a skip away from "Black men can't think, read, write or behave". In this field Entine is not a daring pioneer but the butt-end of a lineage stretching back centuries. In 1884 the Encyclopedia Britannica stated: "No full-blooded negro has ever been distinguished as a man of science, a poet or an artist, and the fundamental equality claimed for him by ignorant philanthropists is belied by the whole history of the race throughout the historic period."

Black people are not the sole targets of this broadside. When Jews were prominent in American basketball during the 20s and 30s the sports editor of the New York Daily News explained that "the game places a premium on an alert, scheming mind, flashy trickiness, artful dodging and general smart-aleckness".

But black people are on the frontline. For there are the equally compelling statistics in the schools, jails and dole queues of the west that tell another story. Black people fall foul not simply of the law of the land but the law of probabilities in everything from employment to the criminal justice system. In the words of Jesse Jackson: "We do well at sport because the playing field is even and the rules are public. But when blacks are kicking up the field and people start making up the rules... that's when the problems start."

"What do they know of cricket who only cricket know?" asked the late Trinidadian intellectual, CLR James. He, more than anyone, understood that sport is not a purely meritocratic endeavour but an integral part of a nation or region's cultural, political and economic makeup. Nowhere is this more obvious than in the Caribbean, where basketball and football are fast overtaking cricket among the young. Two days before the West Indies were humiliated at Headingly, Trinidad and Tobago thrashed Panama at football 6-0. Yesterday's "natural" cricketers are today's "natural" footballers. The switch is not in their genes but in their society.

Moreover, sport is a multi-million pound business for some and a career choice for others. People take the chances that come their way. If discrimination denies them opportunity in one place and offers it to them elsewhere, they will take it. It is not middle-class African-Americans with the chance to become lawyers, doctors and administrators who are rushing to the starting line or the boxing ring but the poor with few other options.

Does this deny any connection between the physiology of black athletes and their sporting achievements? Not entirely, although given all the other far more plausible explanations, I doubt the motives of those who are desperate to establish it. Whatever impact race may have on black people's sporting ability is negligible in comparison to the impact that racism has on their daily lives. So feel free to make the case and I will feel free to be insulted. When the stopping, searching, jailing, bailing, executing, excluding, unemploying and underpaying are over - then, and only then, will I listen to talk of "tendons", "arm spans" and "plasma".

webTitle: Confidence on rise in the black community

fields.headline: Confidence on rise in the black community
fields.standfirst: Special report: race issues in the UK
fields.trailText: Britain's black population is becoming more confident about its culture and also more at ease living in this country, a survey suggests today.
fields.body:
Britain's black population is becoming more confident about its culture and also more at ease living in this country, a survey suggests today.

Ties to the West Indies and Africa are reflected in musical tastes and in traditions of worship, but some style-conscious young adults are spending large sums on fashion, confirming just how the community is setting trends for Britons of all backgrounds.

The survey also indicates that more black people are happy to remain in Britain for their holidays. However, many have strong doubts about the political system. The Black Community Report, published today, suggests too there has been a rise in smoking heavily and in television watching, and a drop in drinking and taking exercise.

The authors of the report, the London-based Peoplescience Intelligence Unit, says blacks feel many aspects of their lives are "strong and well" but "there has been a general feeling among black people that the community has a great deal of untapped potential".

The findings are based on street surveys of nearly 600 blacks aged over 16 in London, Bristol, Birmingham, Nottingham, Manchester and Liverpool. They suggest an increasingly diverse picture, where Afro-Caribbean communities are being matched in some areas by rising numbers of those with more direct links to the African continent.

This is indicated by the musical likes of those questioned.

Reggae still tops the list - with 39% of those questioned naming it as a popular choice, followed by soul (34%), African music (32%), gospel (29%), and hip-hop (24%). Rock music was mentioned by 2%. When it came to choosing an absolute favourite, gospel and African music both attracted 13% of support, followed by reggae at 12%. Rock and jungle languished at well under 1% each.

The strength of religious conviction, indicated by the gospel music figures, is confirmed by the fact that 93% of those questioned said they believed in God, and 73% of them followed a Christian belief system. Nearly one in 10 affirmed the Muslim faith, 6% followed forms of African spirituality, and 4% were Rastafarians.

The rapid growth in black congregations was explained further by one in three saying they attended religious services once a week, up from 20% four years ago, and vastly more than the 7.5% of the English population as a whole found by a study of attendance for all denominations.

There was a huge increase in the number of black people saying they took holidays in Britain - 27%, compared with 10% in 1996.

Europe attracted 26% of those questioned and the US 23%. A fifth went to the Caribbean, and a similar proportion went to Africa. A quarter had not been on holiday anywhere.

While most black adults do not spend more than £25 a week on fashion, beauty and their hair, a fifth spend up to £50, 8% spent up to £75, and 5% spent more than that. Many of the higher spenders were young men.

Drinking appeared to be falling. Four in 10 said they did not drink, an increase on the 31% of 1996. A third of the community said they smoked cigarettes, with one in five admitting to using cannabis, down from 22% four years ago. Only 46% said they played the National Lottery, compared with 60% for the population as a whole.

When asked to rate how well black MPs represented the black community, 19% rated them poorly at 0 to 2, while 15% gave ratings of 8 -10. Four in 10 people did not understand what proportional representation meant.

Yet nearly half those questioned (45%) thought an independent black political party would serve their communities better, against 14% who did not think there would be a difference and 11% who thought that would make matters worse. Another 28% were unsure. With four black MPs in parliament, mainstream parties will be concerned.

webTitle: Arts: The Original Kings of Comedy

fields.headline: Great act guys. Who are you?
fields.standfirst: The crowds flocked to their nationwide comedy tour but the Kings of Comedy were a mystery to white America - until Spike Lee filmed their act.  Allister Harry reports
fields.trailText: The crowds flocked to their nationwide comedy tour but the Kings of Comedy were a mystery to white America - until Spike Lee filmed their act. Allister Harry reports.
fields.body:
Spike Lee's latest movie is a riot of laughs. It ought to be: it records a stand-up performance by four black comedians whose nationwide act is the most successful comedy tour ever. And the funny thing is, most white Americans have never heard of them.

The comics - Steve Harvey, DL Hughley, Cedric the Entertainer and Bernie Mac - have set records in New York's Madison Square Garden and taken Washington DC's MCI Centre by storm. The tour has grossed $37m in two years, but most critics are still scratching their heads, wondering where the four came from.

The film, The Original Kings of Comedy, is likely to change all that. "I wanted to see this [tour] on film because it had to be documented," says Lee. "Being on film would enable a lot more people to see it. This was a cultural event. The people who came out for this saved their money, bought new outfits and really got worked up. It was the most successful comedy tour ever and mainstream America didn't even really know about it."

The film took $12m in its opening weekend in the US. It is already being compared to black comedy concert classics such as Richard Pryor Live on the Sunset Strip, Martin Lawrence's You So Crazy and Eddie Murphy's Raw. Variety said The Original Kings of Comedy was "consistently hilarious" and Lee "conveys a palpable sense of the rousing, communal energy of the live performance."

It was filmed over two nights in February at the Charlotte Coliseum in North Carolina, where the tour had kicked off in 1997. Lee used 12 cameras, two of them weaving among the audience. Each comedian does his set in turn. Host Harvey's speciality is satire, his comedy perhaps smarter than the others: he rants against rap music and tells the story of a black sportsman who fled to Nashville to escape the police, "like they ain't gonna find your black ass there". Hughley, with his wry, scathing wit, verbally beats up the audience and attacks bad jobs, bad bosses and grandparents who take Viagra. Cedric is the lovable, mischievous, rotund one who sings, dances, juggles his gags and does hilarious impressions of golf-playing black people trying to make like Tiger Woods. And Mac, with his bug-eyes and raspy voice, is all in your face, raw and hardcore, making jokes about beating the kids.

So why have these comedians suddenly made it? The key words are "relatively unknown". Harvey, for instance, is not a household name in the US. But his self-titled sitcom is starting its fifth season on the WB network and is one of the most popular TV shows in black households; he also hosts a Showtime at the Apollo TV series. Mac has appeared in numerous movies including Life, Friday, and Spike Lee's Get On the Bus. Cedric the Entertainer hosted Black Entertainment Television's stand-up show, Comic View, in 1994, the year he won the channel's Richard Pryor comic of the year award. Hughley has his own self-titled sitcom, The Hughleys, based on his experience of moving from the 'hood to the 'burbs, and like Cedric the Entertainer has been tearing up the black comedy circuit for years.

So although the four were not big mainstream names, they had high profiles among their target audience. The established pattern is to build a following on the circuit, secure a sitcom which increases your profile, then go for the big one - Hollywood maybe - where your hard-won audience will ensure the black dollars come flooding in. It is a tradition of black American comedy, begun by Richard Pryor in the 70s and followed by Eddie Murphy in the 80s, Chris Rock in the 90s, and Martin Lawrence and Chris Tucker now.

fields.headline: M&S fails to stem clothing sales fall
fields.standfirst: Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: Marks & Spencer was dealt a fresh blow yesterday when leaked documents revealed a fall in its clothing sales, despite its restyled range and revamped image.
fields.body:
Marks & Spencer was dealt a fresh blow yesterday when leaked documents revealed a fall in its clothing sales, despite its restyled range and revamped image.

The revelation of a 6% decline in sales is a particular embarrassment as it comes days before a new corporate advertising campaign is expected to begin. The decline is also expected to increase pressure on the M&S share price, which has slumped to its lowest levels for a decade.

According to weekend reports, non-food sales in M&S' 297 stores across the country fell 6% in the week ending August 19, compared with a year ago. Food sales, which account for 40% of turnover, rose during the period.

The figures conflict with reports that the retailer's so-called "concept" stores in three flagship sites were achieving higher sales.

M&S refused to confirm that the leaked documents were authentic or accurate. However, a spokeswoman said that the group had already reported that sales in the concept stores - where the lighting is brighter and clothes arranged differently - were going "very well".

She added the group planned to roll out 23 more concept stores by Christmas.

fields.standfirst:
The rightwing papers' coverage of the bloody loyalist feud in Northern Ireland has been slanted to fit the old myth that republicans are the root of all evil
Special report: Northern Ireland
fields.trailText: The rightwing papers' coverage of the bloody loyalist feud in Northern Ireland has been slanted to fit the old myth that republicans are the root of all evil.
fields.body:
It's often said that, at their best, newspapers provide the first rough draft of history. What is too often overlooked is that, at their second-best, which is more normally the case anyway, papers deny the existence of history.

There are many reasons, and the prime one is the most obvious: news is, by its very nature, immediate. It is, supposedly, new and different and it would be inappropriate to set every event in its historical context.

News is also the main part of a commodity. It must help to sell the paper and would lose its commercial impact if its freshness was undermined by referring to the fact that it has happened before, is not really unique at all and, seen in that light, quite inconsequential. Giving readers a historical perspective takes up space and draws heavily on the time - and, of course, the expertise - of the journalist. It is therefore costly and, given the cult of youth that pervades so many papers nowadays, there are often too few people around editorial floors with a working knowledge of post-war modern history.

Perhaps the most pernicious reason for our ahistorical press is its political agenda. When events call into question a policy line avidly pursued by a paper, throwing into doubt the trenchant "advice" offered to readers down the years, then it proves convenient to ignore history altogether.

A combination of these factors, with the last undoubtedly the most prevalent, occurred in the coverage of loyalist gang warfare in Northern Ireland last week. Rightwing papers suddenly found themselves in a tricky situation because the story did not fit neatly into the previous 30-year pattern of events.

In that paradigm, all the troubles in the "province" stemmed from malevolent republicans. In recent years, with the IRA ceasefire and Sinn Fein's incorporation into elected office, these papers have opened a second front by pouring scorn on the concept and the practice of the peace process.

Yet the vast majority of republicans have remained stubbornly faithful to the ballot box, making it difficult for the hostile Daily Telegraph, Daily Mail, Times and Sun to continue with their anti-peace process propaganda war.

Then along comes Johnny "Mad Dog" Adair and an opportunity of sorts is gratefully accepted. The usual suspects - Ruth Dudley-Edwards, Michael Gove, Bruce Anderson - were wheeled out along with their unnamed leader-writing sympathisers to hammer the government.

The outbreak of internecine strife on the Shankill was, according to Anderson in the Mail, due to politicians having created "a moral vacuum in which such madness can fester".

Gove in the Times blamed John Major and Tony Blair for appeasement. The Telegraph referred to the Northern Ireland secretary, Peter Mandelson, as living in an "Alice in Wonderland world" and claimed that Adair "ruled the roost because of the Belfast agreement". So far, so bad. Even on this single point, no historical context was allowed to peep through. No mention, for instance, of the people of Ireland having voted overwhelmingly for the agreement, which stated categorically that prisoners would be released.

The Times, unlike the Telegraph, did at least praise Mandelson for Adair's arrest. But its columnist Gove led the way in offering a scandalous justification for the Protestant paramilitaries' gangsterism.Their hostility towards the peace process, he dared to claim, is fuelled by the fact that Sinn Fein's Martin McGuinness is in government.

And there, of course, is the return to the central agenda: it's all the uppity republicans' fault after all. The Daily Mail nodded in agreement, referring to "the government's endless concessions to republicans".

The Sun, smoothly eliding loyalist gangs with the Provisionals, muddied the waters still further by asserting that "the IRA runs its protection and drug rackets". For years, journalists - and the RUC - have tried, and failed, to make this claim stick. Yet, without a shred of evidence, the Sun is happy to repeat the lie because, even with two loyalist gangs killing each other, it is important to remind readers of the main enemy.

Similarly, a Telegraph leader informed us that "some senior policemen... now believe that republican and loyalist paramilitaries could soon become big players... on the mainland drugs scene".

In a somewhat different approach to the problem of damning republicans while excusing the loyalist thugs, Dudley-Edwards' commentary in the Mail was a triumph of illogicality. The gangsters, she said were suffering from "a feeling of statelessness and injustice". They come from "a strong tradition of dissent" in which "individualism is a key feature" which makes "unionism and loyalism... full of division". This contrasts with republicans who "flourish because they speak with the same voice in a way reminiscent of the Soviet Union".

But there was a more objective voice in the Times, pointing to the very real differences between the two traditions and offering a glimpse of the history, albeit partial, which every other writer overlooked. Simon Jenkins recalled the murderous 1973 Protestant uprising and the fact that down the years it is unionist paramilitaries who have been "more terrifying" than the IRA. In a wonderfully illuminating anecdote he wrote: "Republican library books in the Maze were about politics and literature, loyalist ones about bodybuilding."

In the Daily Express, where we were thankfully spared the Peter Hitchens viewpoint, there was another sensible piece by Cal McCrystal, who is certainly no republican. It was the loyalist ghettos, he wrote, where gangsterism, drug-pushing and prostitution were rife.

But the overall picture painted by papers that gave the story space (did the Mirror really think six paragraphs on Adair's jailing served its readers?) was depressingly devoid of a truly historical perspective. The Mad Dogs and King Rats of the Protestant heartlands are not a new phenomenon. Their predecessors attacked the civil rights marchers and burned Catholic families from their homes in Belfast. It was the old IRA's failure to protect nationalists from these tartan gangs which led to the formation of the Provisionals, and the failure of the British troops (well, the British government) to recognise the true villains of the piece that led them into confrontation with the Provos.

It was also the loyalist mobs who destroyed the government's 1974 attempt at power-sharing. No wonder British people routinely say of the northern Irish: "They're all as bad as each other." That's what their papers keep telling them.

fields.body:
Meanwhile . . . in Britain

It is just two months before the UK gets its first taste of a personal TV service. Making the first move in this market is TiVo, which has the first-mover advantage and effectively guaranteed its success by signing a two-year exclusive 50/50 deal with Sky. Competitor Replay TV is remaining tight-lipped about any plans to come to Europe, although it has been rumoured to be in discussions with all the terrestrial broadcasters. Unless it enters the market within the next six months, however, it is widely believed that it will have lost too much ground to TiVo to be able to make any headway in the UK.

It is hard to see how Sky can lose, because the biggest threat to TiVo is software company NDS - the News Corp company which developed Sky Sports Active and is widely tipped to be the supplier of personal video recorder (PVR) software to Sky's next-generation set-top box. The deal would mean that NDS's digital PVR software, XTV, would be incorporated into set-top boxes early next year and offered to all Sky subscribers for an additional monthly subscription.

The Sky-TiVo boxes (minus the Sky branding) are to go on sale in October and will be distributed both through Sky call centres and high-street outlets such as Dixons stores and Granada's Box Clever. It is thought that the TiVo boxes will initially cost around £399 to buy, with a £10 monthly subscription.

Sky is currently signing up broadcasting partners to rent space on the "showcases" section of the electronic programme guide (EPG), where they can promote programmes or new channels. This additional service is initially being offered free of charge to all UK channels, with the condition that as the subscriber base grows this will be changed to a subscription/rental model. The BBC was the first broadcaster, apart from Sky, to sign a two-year deal for this service, although other channels are expected to be signed up before launch.

fields.headline: Box of tricks
fields.standfirst:
It records and stores your favourite programmes. It culls the ads. It will even do your channel surfing for you. This device, Michael Lewis argues, heralds not just a technological revolution, but the end of commercial television as we know it
Net news
fields.trailText: It records and stores your favourite programmes. It culls the ads. It will even do your channel surfing for you. This device, Michael Lewis argues, heralds not just a technological revolution, but the end of commercial television as we know it.
fields.body:
The current phase of American capitalism began on November 9 1989, with the formal collapse of socialism. Since then, a lot of new technology has arrived to enhance market forces. The internet is one such technology. In a few short years, it has pretty much gutted the principles of corporate socialism - jobs for life; employee and customer loyalty; all for one and one for all - and replaced them with Lord knows what.

Any time line that describes this phase of American capitalism would also have to include April 4 1994 (birth of Netscape), November 10 1994 (birth of Amazon.com), May 5 1996 (birth of eBay) - and August 4 1997. August 4 1997 was the beginning of the end of another socialistic force in American life: the mass market. Forty years from now, when your grandson asks you, "Grandma, how did 50m Americans ever let themselves be talked into buying the same mouthwash?" you will say, "Well, you have to know how things were before August 4 1997."

This was the day a pair of Silicon Valley engineers named Jim Barton and Mike Ramsay started their own technology company with several million dollars from a pair of venture capital firms. Barton and Ramsay's first idea was to turn the American home into a network, but, after a few months, they went back to their venture capitalists and told them that home networking was a bad idea because they couldn't explain it to anyone but other geeks. They had another idea, though. Instead of transforming the entire American home, they decided to focus on the television.

Barton had become obsessed with the television a few years earlier, when working at Silicon Graphics. He helped to build the only interactive television that actually worked, installed in late 1994 by Time Warner in 4,000 homes in Orlando, Florida, and then watched in dismay as his beloved project was overrun by the internet. The internet did a fraction of what the new TVs promised, but at a fraction of the price.

Like many smart engineers, Bar ton is a man used to figuring things out. The TV gnawed at him because he didn't have the answer. The box worked. And yet no one cared. There were several lessons in this:

No 1 Brilliant gadgets for a mass market do not go anywhere if the masses cannot afford them.

No 2 A big company is not necessarily the best place to create a revolutionary technology.

No 3 The whims of the American consumer are the eighth wonder of the world. They can wreak havoc with the most powerful establishments.

When Barton and Ramsay returned to the television, they devised another black box, one with a memory. Far simpler to programme than a VCR, it was also considerably more versatile. The viewer could record programming. Or he could simply tell the box to go out and find him the kind of programmes he liked. If he liked indiscreet women, he could record and store every episode of Sex and the City. If he liked intelligent blood and guts, he didn't need to wait until TNT's Clint Eastwood week - he could just instruct his box to fetch Clint Eastwood movies as they played. The viewer's only constraint on choice was that the programme had to be broadcast by someone, sometime.

The black box also enabled the viewer to treat all television - even live television - as television he had recorded for his own private use. All he would need to do is start watching a programme a few minutes after it began. Then, by pressing a button, he could skip the credits, the time-outs, the weather and all the other boring stretches of television designed by producers to lull viewers into watching ads. He could also skip the ads.

Over time, the viewer would create his own private TV channel, stored on a hard drive in the black box, tailored with great precision to his interests. When someone asked Barton or Ramsay, "Tell me again what this gadget does?" they now had a simple answer: "It lets you watch anything you want to watch when you want to watch it."

There was one other cool thing the box could do. While the viewer watched the television, the box would watch the viewer. The viewer's every decision would be stored in a kind of private museum of whims. Over time, the box would come to know what the viewer liked - maybe even better than the viewer himself. All by itself, it would record shows it calculated the viewer might like. The box was more than a box, it was a butler, and the more it learned about its master's whims, the more it would be able to fetch what its master wanted.

Calling their company TiVo, Ramsay, 50, the chief executive officer, and Barton, 42, the chief technology officer, knew the box was not where the money was - the box was, in fact, a big money loser. To kick-start the market they would need to pay an electronics company to make the boxes and sell them below cost. The trick was to get as many into American homes as possible. TiVo's programming software would arrive in millions of homes either with existing cable boxes or, in the future, embedded in new TV sets, cable boxes or satellite receivers. The long-term goal was to become unnecessary. "We'll know we've succeeded when the TiVo box vanishes," Barton says.

The ambition of the enterprise was breathtaking. The company intended to plop itself down between the 102m TV homes and the $50bn TV industry. Once the box was in place, TiVo would be the hub of the TV industry. The company would know the subtle preferences of every viewer. Meanwhile . . . in Britain

It is just two months before the UK gets its first taste of a personal TV service, writes Amy Vickers. Making the first move in this market is TiVo, which has the first-mover advantage and effectively guaranteed its success by signing a two-year exclusive 50/50 deal with Sky. Competitor Replay TV is remaining tight-lipped about any plans to come to Europe, although it has been rumoured to be in discussions with all the terrestrial broadcasters. Unless it enters the market within the next six months, however, it is widely believed that it will have lost too much ground to TiVo to be able to make any headway in the UK.

It is hard to see how Sky can lose, because the biggest threat to TiVo is software company NDS - the News Corp company which developed Sky Sports Active and is widely tipped to be the supplier of personal video recorder (PVR) software to Sky's next-generation set-top box. The deal would mean that NDS's digital PVR software, XTV, would be incorporated into set-top boxes early next year and offered to all Sky subscribers for an additional monthly subscription.

The Sky-TiVo boxes (minus the Sky branding) are to go on sale in October and will be distributed both through Sky call centres and high-street outlets such as Dixons stores and Granada's Box Clever. It is thought that the TiVo boxes will initially cost around £399 to buy, with a £10 monthly subscription.

Sky is currently signing up broadcasting partners to rent space on the "showcases" section of the electronic programme guide (EPG), where they can promote programmes or new channels. This additional service is initially being offered free of charge to all UK channels, with the condition that as the subscriber base grows this will be changed to a subscription/rental model. The BBC was the first broadcaster, apart from Sky, to sign a two-year deal for this service, although other channels are expected to be signed up before launch.
