fields.headline: Money matters
fields.standfirst: Ecuador's government hopes dollarisation will bring stability; others lament the loss of their own currency, the sucre.
fields.trailText: Ecuador's government hopes dollarisation will bring stability; others lament the loss of their own currency, the sucre.
fields.body:
August brings clear skies and a blazing sun to Quito. The thin Andean air carries the scent of woodsmoke, incense - and a whiff of teargas. But outside the battered congress building, few passersby look twice at yet another stand-off between demonstrators and riot police.

In a country that has seen six presidents in five years, political chaos is taken for granted. Governments come and go, but Ecuador is now bracing for a change with much deeper symbolic significance. Hoping to brake runaway inflation and promote foreign investment, the government has decided to base the economy on the US dollar. Next month, the country's currency, the sucre, will disappear.

"It's like losing part of your body," says Ximena Chavez, working at an internet cafe in the leafy Mariscal Sucre neighbourhood. Like the doomed currency, the area is named after the national hero who liberated Quito from the Spanish. "My children will only read about the sucre in history books," she says.

On a street corner in the bustling city centre, lottery saleswoman Petrona Sanchez is equally bewildered. Dressed in the traditional shawl and bead necklaces of the Quichua Indians, she pulls out a handful of dimes, nickels and quarters from a pouch at her waist. "I don't understand them. They don't even have numbers on them," she says.

Dollarisation was the last card in ex-president Jamil Mahuad's tattered pack of policies. He announced it in January, days before he was ousted by Indian protests and a military coup. Opposition groups hoped the uprising would bury the scheme, but Mahuad's sucessor, Gustavo Noboa, forged ahead, saying that dollarisation was the only way to bring stability to the economy. The value of the sucre had plunged from 7,000 to the dollar in January 1999 to nearly 30,000 at the start of 2000.

Most of the old coins and notes have already been withdrawn, but with 70% of the country's population living in poverty, the dollar is proving to be well out of proportion with most Ecuadorians' spending needs. Except in tourist hotels and restaurants, it is nearly impossible to pay with anything over a $5 note. The government plans to issue Ecuadorian coins with the same value as the US ones, but at the moment, nobody has any change.

In a toyshop, The Virgin of Consolation Bazaar, it takes several minutes of hotly debated arithmetic for a small boy to buy a pair of Pokemon dolls. He hands over one crisp dollar bill and 40,000 sucres in coins and stained notes. Maria Suarez, the shopkeeper, gives him 10 cents and a 500 sucre piece in change.

"It's not that complicated. I have a calculator," she says. Like most shopkeepers, taxi drivers and street vendors, Mrs Suarez still hasn't got round to changing her price list to dollars. "But I think dollarisation is for the better," she says. "Before, the sucre got weaker every day. The dollar is much more stable."

But critics of the plan say that while the switch to the dollar has stabilised Ecuador's foreign exchange, it has yet to stop inflation. "Dollarisation will bring stability to the people - the stability of knowing they are poor and will stay poor for a long time," said economist Alberto Acosta, who fears that a dollar-based economy will force prices up to international levels and reinforce the gulf between the rich and poor.

Others are more sanguine. Outside the 16th-century church of San Francisco, Graciela Bonilla's market stall is crowded with votary candles, rosaries and amulets. Jammed between a plaster cast of the Virgin and a statue of the Buddha is a bowl full of magnets and odd bits of metal. Amid the horse shoes and pig iron there is a handful of old coins withdrawn from circulation in the 1990s.

"They're good against the evil eye, but they're not worth anything," says Mrs Bonilla, "Coins are like politicians. When they're no use any more, we just throw them away."

fields.headline: Celebrity shares
fields.standfirst: In theory it's simple. The big name endorses your internet business in return for a stake - and everyone makes loads of money. In practice, it's a bit trickier, says Amy Vickers.
fields.trailText: In theory it's simple. The big name endorses your internet business in return for a stake - and everyone makes loads of money. In practice, it's a bit trickier, says Amy Vickers.
fields.body:
Times are certainly changing. Was it really only a few years back that the internet was primarily the domain of low-end tech-savvy users and the only celebrity endorsements we were privy to were the likes of Nanette Newman touting Fairy liquid? Nowadays, it seems that wherever you look on the web you can't avoid stumbling across famous names endorsing a new website or throwing their weight behind their own new internet venture.

The reasons are obvious: most celebrities hanker after any kind of media promotion and if getting involved in an internet venture also manages to give them additional kudos, then that has to be a good thing. The glut of coverage at the start of this year about the fame and fortune that the internet brings only served to encourage the feelings of dot.com envy, and even though this has been replaced recently by feelings of dot.com disenchantment, the internet is still seen as a future-proof investment strategy.

The latest entrant into this territory is Clive James, antipodean journalist-cum-TV presenter. James is not ready to shy away from what, in his words, represents his next big challenge. At a press lunch in London two weeks ago, James touted the wares of Welcome Stranger, an internet start-up aimed at people who travel.

Having managed to pull off a fine performance selling his involvement in Welcomestranger.com at the lunch, James then set about telling us that the company needed £500,000 to move the business on to the next stage. fields.headline: The best breaking news scene: Cherry Falls
fields.trailText: On the steps of George Washington High School, Cherry Falls, Virginia, the students are abuzz, having learned of the gruesome murder of two of their classmates. Timmy (Keram Malicki-Sanchez), the impossibly camp editor of the school newspaper, breathlessly greets his closest friend, Jody Marken (Britanny Murphy), daughter of the local sherrif.
fields.body:
On the steps of George Washington High School, Cherry Falls, Virginia, the students are abuzz, having learned of the gruesome murder of two of their classmates. Timmy (Keram Malicki-Sanchez), the impossibly camp editor of the school newspaper, breathlessly greets his closest friend, Jody Marken (Britanny Murphy), daughter of the local sherrif.

"Jody, doll, listen, I'm trying to pump out a special edition of the paper before lunchtime, and if you tell me all that you know I'll be your best friend, your very, very best friend, and you can be co-editor of the paper to apply to all those Ivy League schools with those young meritable boys. Whaddya think?"

Jody tries to reply, but Timmy continues before she can speak.

"No, no, no, don't be silent like that. I want you to talk to your Dad and Snoop Dog for me - you know what I'm saying?"

She shakes her head.

"Timmy, I don't have a clue what you're talking about."

Timmy's jaw drops.

" What? You haven't heard about Rod and Stacey?"

"Oh, are you taking notes for your pathetic little column? Did they break up?"

"Break up? Wake up! They're dead. They flatlined, they shuffled off this mortal coil, they've croaked and gone to see their maker. Duh! How can you be so critically uninformed? Will you look around you - the whole school's buzzing with that music."

Jody turns to see a multitude of students on the steps beside her, crying and hugging.

See also: All The President's Men, Scream

Don't see also: Independence Day

Pointless trivia: Brittany Murphy's real first name is Sharon.

fields.headline: Land of make believe
fields.standfirst: In BBC1's new series Down to Earth, a married couple flee London and buy a farm. If you've ever watched The Good Life - or All Creatures Great And Small - you'll know the routine
fields.trailText: In BBC1's new series Down to Earth, a married couple flee London and buy a farm. If you've ever watched The Good Life - or All Creatures Great And Small - you'll know the routine.
fields.body:
One of the fiddliest aspects of writing fiction is handing out names to the characters. Inadvertently give your invented fraudulent councillor the name of an honest real one, and your royalties will be going to lawyers. You can usually tell a writer who's been sued because their plots start being peopled by types called Eduardo Styrofoam-Heffalump.

Another risk is symbolism: the optimist called Hope, the pessimist surnamed Drudge. In BBC1's Down to Earth, a six-part drama about a London couple starting over in Devon as farmers, Warren Clarke plays a husband called Brian, Pauline Quirke a wife called Faith.

These christenings at once send signals to the audience. In the BBC's previous self-sufficiency series, The Good Life, the central characters were actually called Good in order to accommodate the title pun, but sit-com has more licence in that respect, and here Brian and Faith's surname is Addis. Their first names do all the symbolic work.

In fiction, Brians tend to be working-class, reliable and plodding. The name is a playground insult for thick. And this is precisely the surface personality which Warren Clarke likes to portray in his performances (Nice Work, Dalziel & Pascoe) before revealing a greater inner complexity. The name Faith is so pointed, a wizard could wear it as a hat. Although solid and dependable like her husband, this designation marks Brian's wife as a visionary and dreamer.

And, indeed, episode one turns literally on one of her dreams: she wakes after a nocturnal sub-conscious journey through hayfields to announce that the family will downshift to Devon. Brian is doubtful about whether he can do this but Faith, as badged by the dramatist, has faith in him. But perhaps it's no surprise that the names are so carefully weighted. Down to Earth is scripted by Ashley Pharaoh, who must have endured a lifetime of jokes about pyramids and multi-coloured coats.

In comparison with The Good Life 20 years ago, the biggest difference in Down to Earth is the social shading. The central characters in The Good Life were either middle-class (Tom and Barbara) or pseudo-upper (Jerry and Margot). Brian and Faith are a florist and a teacher with obvious working-class roots.

British TV is oddly the opposite of society in this respect. When there was a large and identifiable working class, TV characters were all middle. Apart from Tom and Barbara Good, the other great fictional downshifter of the 70s was Peter Barkworth's back-to-basics bank manager in Telford's Change. But, now that the TV audience is dominated by a vast and expanding middle-class, the screens teem with a fictional prole tariat. Cockney and estuary speech have become associated with decency. The series' title - Down to Earth - is as loaded as the central characters' names. Brian and Faith are down to earth. In this series, only the villains (a VAT inspector, a Devon estate agent) speak BBC English.

Confused over class, TV drama also tends to have trouble with money. It's often pointed out that characters tend to live well beyond their financial means. This is because TV drama is like a movie star: it always wants to look as beautiful as possible. The people in Friends, for example, must have a secret drug-running business to rent their smart apartment. Middle-ranking policemen on TV tend to have riverside penthouses so they can stare at their reflection in the water while contemplating the evidence.

Typically, Down to Earth can never decide how much cash Brian and Faith have. The dialogue insists that money is tight. Brian is not VAT-registered, which puts his income at less than £20,000. But Faith stays in a country house hotel while looking for a knock-down farm to buy. About to be gazumped on a property, they hire a private plane and fly to Devon.

A key line of dialogue establishes the series as a modern fable - the profits of Brian's florist shop have been hit by internet and supermarket delivery services - and its most contemporary mark is a pastoral sentimentality. The joke in The Good Life was that the farming took place in Surrey. Like the contemporaneous Reginald Perrin sitcoms, it attacked not where people lived but where they worked: in zombifying nine-to-five offices. In Down to Earth, the characters' motivation is to get away from London. The poem which Faith is teaching her slow-track English class is The Wasteland. The roads are gridlocked, Brian and Faith's daughter at the local comp is dangerously in love with a criminal lad. The couple's sex life, dried up in London, is revived in Devon.

Down to Earth is also a very 21st-century drama in its relationship to other TV shows, not just to The Good Life. At the end of the first episode, Brian has to deliver a calf. When he asks what he's supposed to do, his family give meaningful looks. "Oh, nooooooo," he says.

Schooled by scenes from All Creatures Great And Small to Vets In Practice, viewers know that he's required to put his arm up the cow's backside. It's a perfect illustration of how, as the medium ages, so much television is about other television.

TV on trial

Television programmes divide into dozens of categories, but one of the most select is the small group of shows which have moved between ITV and the BBC.

You could include the BBC's impending concept-theft of News At Ten, Men Behaving Badly (dropped by ITV as a flop, turned into a hit by BBC) and, most mysteriously, This Is Your Life, which limps on like an ex-Premiership footballer turning out each weekend in the Vauxhall Conference and ignoring aching limbs.

The most welcome transfer, however, is Hypotheticals (Tuesday to Thursday, 11.20pm, BBC2), which Granada made for ITV but now produces for the BBC, although its regrettable shift to late-night slots even there suggests that the series may be heading for a further transfer to BBC4 or another of the Dyke-pioneered minority services.

Hypotheticals was designed to avoid the problem of professional confidentiality. Doctors, police chiefs, social workers, priests and politicians were unable to discuss specific cases. In these shows, arranged around a horseshoe table, they react in character to a fictional scenario which, like a moral game of consequences, becomes ever more contemplated.

Tuesday's opening scenario begins with doctors drinking in a pub where a man collapses, and expands to take in numerous questions of medical responsibility, touching on Alder Hey and Shipman and other headline medical stories in light disguise. The incidental revelations include the fact that the NHS is permitted to prescribe only one Viagra tablet per person per week.

The plot is unfolded by a "moderator", a role previously filled most often by Geoffrey Robertson, QC. In this series, a spoiled lawyer, Clive Anderson, leads two shows, bringing more gags than usual to the table, and Anesta Weekes, a QC at the Stephen Lawrence trial, makes a debut which continues BBC2's recent attempt to look less male.

fields.headline: Twenty years of hurt
fields.standfirst: He may be a hero of English football, but Stuart Pearce has won surprisingly little. Perhaps that's why he's still playing at 38.  Stephen Moss meets the man affectionately known as Psycho
fields.trailText: He may be a hero of English football, but Stuart Pearce has won surprisingly little. Perhaps that's why he's still playing at 38. Stephen Moss meets the man affectionately known as Psycho.
fields.body:
A look in the car park at West Ham's training ground in Ilford tells you a good deal about Stuart Pearce. While the Hammers' flamboyant star striker, Paolo Di Canio, slides into his state-of the-art silver Jaguar, Pearce makes do with a bright red Mondeo. ("It was only delivered yesterday," he says proudly.) Di Canio might win all the headlines, but Pearce is assured of the undying affection of Mondeo Men everywhere.

Pearce, affectionately known as Psycho, is the People's Player, and it seems appropriate that he should be finishing his playing career - he is now 38, antediluvian by football standards - at West Ham. Even in this shiny, superficial corporate age, the Hammers remain loyal to their roots as a family club, a club that represents a tough pocket of East London. At the training ground a couple of hundred fans have gathered to ogle their idols and collect autographs. Pearce only joined last year, but he is already a folk hero here.

Last season, Pearce broke his leg twice, enough you would think to finish the career of most players, let alone one who has played in the Premiership for the best part of two decades. But this season he is back in the first team, on a monthly contract, naturally taking each game as it comes, because at his age that's the way it has to be.

A couple of years ago, when the then Newcastle manager Ruud Gullit decided that Pearce was finished as a player and humiliated him by playing youngsters in place of the seasoned international, he was ready to quit. But West Ham manager Harry Redknapp offered him a contract and Pearce, eager to prove Gullit wrong, jumped at it.

"I was a week away from retiring," he says. "If Harry hadn't come in to get me, and if he hadn't been so supportive when I broke my leg twice last season, I wouldn't still be playing. When I broke my leg for the second time, he said 'we'll stick by you, get yourself right, and there'll be a new contract here for you'. There aren't many managers who would do that."

fields.headline: New snag hits Scottish exams
fields.standfirst: Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: Scotland's education crisis deepened yesterday when it emerged that further administrative problems at the Scottish qualifications authority may delay a new exam system.
fields.body:
Scotland's education crisis deepened yesterday when it emerged that further administrative problems at the Scottish qualifications authority may delay a new exam system.

Problems in issuing paperwork by the authority mean some schools do not have the material they need for the new advanced higher course work.

The authority is already under fire for the results chaos that has left thousands of pupils who sat this year's exams unsure of their academic future.

The advanced highers will replace the old certificate of sixth year studies and schools had been told to expect the material for the new courses by June. However, it has become clear that many schools are still waiting their materials to be sent.

"In some areas all the material is complete and in some subjects there are delays but this delay should not stop anyone going ahead with the advanced highers," a spokesman for the Scottish executive said yesterday. A spokeswoman for the SQA said it had issued national assessment materials for most major subjects and that all materials for advanced highers should be received this month.

She said the authority tackled the subjects likely to have the highest take-up first.

But she refused to comment on whether this would lead to a delay on advanced highers courses starting in schools.

She said the administrative delay had been caused by the high volume of materials needing to be produced and the fact that they had to be written by subject specialists.

Meanwhile, it has also emerged that the Scottish executive's chief adviser on education, the man responsible for the implementation of the new exam structure, has been in Australia while the exams crisis has been unfolding.

Douglas Osler, chief schools inspector, is said to be on holiday before attending an education administrators conference in Tasmania in September, where he will be the keynote speaker.

webTitle: Labour offer of apprentice place for all youngsters

fields.headline: Labour offer of apprentice place for all youngsters
fields.standfirst: Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: Labour is to promise an apprenticeship place to all 16 to 18-year-olds in a skills and training package which is set to be included in the party's manifesto.
fields.body:
Labour is to promise an apprenticeship place to all 16 to 18-year-olds in a skills and training package which is set to be included in the party's manifesto.

David Blunkett, the education and employment secretary, wants to address the 100,000 16- and 17-year-olds who "drop out" every year, and neither stay on in education nor go into work. A report published this year by the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development said Britain had a poor record in smoothing the transition to work for young people.

Mr Blunkett believes that the guarantee, to be in place for September 2001, maps a route for young people to aim for if they choose not to stay in full-time education. The proposal, agreed at Labour's national policy forum in July, goes before the party conference next month and is very likely to form a plank of the manifesto.

Most apprenticeships will be organised by the private sector. But Mr Blunkett is confident that the public sector, which pays fees to training colleges, can expand if necessary. About 250,000 16 to 18-year-olds are on private and public schemes - 80,000 have been taken on under the government's modern apprenticeship scheme. Mr Blunkett wants to expand these numbers.

He also proposes to give union "learning representatives" a legal right to paid release from work. A union learning fund launched by the Department for Education and Employment in 1997 has established 2,000 learning representatives in large and medium-sized companies.

Backed by the fund, worth £10m, the representatives encourage and advise workers on further training and negotiate with employers to get time and facilities to do it.

Though the details are not finalised, Mr Blunkett wants to put learning representatives on a statutory footing. He believes they can become "footsoldiers" for raising skills standards, and "workplace experts" on skills issues. Smaller firms that are exempt from trade union legislation will not be affected.

Mr Blunkett also said he had brokered an agreement by employers and unions on an alternative to restoring a training levy. Labour ended its long-held policy in support of training levies, which legally obliged firms to fund training in their sector, in 1996.

Mr Blunkett wants to nurture existing training schemes agreed voluntarily within a particular industry sector and, where employers and union request, support the scheme through law. Some sectors are opposed to a training levy. But in others, big companies and unions support it because it sidelines cowboy firms. For instance, in the construction industry, there is a skills contribution scheme, backed by employers and unions and renewed each year.

Mr Blunkett is particularly keen on transferable training loans being piloted by the gas industry, where big companies fund training. Under the plan, individual companies do not lose their investment when an employee they have trained moves to another company in the sector.

Mr Blunkett believes the scheme could become a blueprint for elsewhere and, if successful, he would be prepared to give it statutory backing.

He is also promising to strengthen national training organisations, funded by employers with government and European Union money, that promote skills in 76 sectors ranging from accountancy to the water industry.

 The Institute of Directors yesterday called for improvements to the modern apprenticeship scheme. They also demanded more resources to made available for smaller firms to help train employees, and communication and information technology skills to made integral to courses.

Only 14% of British workers had intermediate level vocational qualifications, compared with 46% of employees in Germany, the institute pointed out in a report.

webTitle: Report calls for six-term school year

fields.headline: Report calls for six-term school year
fields.standfirst: Eductaion Unlimited
fields.trailText: Teachers' fears about losing their biggest perk - the long summer holiday - will resurface this week when an influential local authority commission recommends introduction of a six-term academic year.
fields.body:
Teachers' fears about losing their biggest perk - the long summer holiday - will resurface this week when an influential local authority commission recommends introduction of a six-term academic year.

In a package of changes to the traditional school calendar, a commission set up by the Local Government Association will also call for GCSE and A-level exams to be brought forward to as early as April to allow students to apply to university and other courses after they have their results.

In a report to be published on Friday and presented to government, the commission, headed by the former Labour MP, Chris Price, will recommend that the three-term school year be reorganised into six terms of a more even length.

The LGA, which represents local education authorities, wants a debate on the implications of a shake-up to the school year, which until now has been strongly resisted by teacher unions.

Private polling by the commission is understood to have shown that parents are overwhelmingly in favour of changes because of childcare considerations and the cost of taking holidays at peak times.

Graham Lane, LGA education spokesman, commented: "Teachers are creatures of habit. It is time we moved with the times.

"There must be scope for some more flexibility."
